subtopics.title: Introduction
subtopics.content:
üìò Learning Module ‚Äì Data Handling (Grade 7)

üåü Introduction

In our daily lives, we come across lots of information in the form of numbers‚Äîsuch as the scores in a cricket match, marks obtained by students, or daily temperatures. This collection of information is called data.

To make sense of data, we must collect, organize, and represent it in a simple and meaningful way. This process is known as Data Handling.

subtopics.title: Data
subtopics.content:
1. Data

Data is a collection of facts, numbers, or observations.

Example: Marks of 5 students = 12, 15, 18, 10, 20.

subtopics.title: Organization of Data
subtopics.content:
2. Organization of Data

  • Raw data can be confusing.
  • We use tables, tallies, and charts to organize data.
  • Frequency: The number of times a value occurs.

Example:
Marks scored: 10, 12, 15, 10, 12, 10
‚Üí Frequency of 10 = 3, frequency of 12 = 2, frequency of 15 = 1

subtopics.title: Pictograph
subtopics.content:
3. Pictograph

A pictograph uses pictures or symbols to represent data.

Example: If üçé = 5 apples, then üçéüçé = 10 apples.

subtopics.title: Bar Graph
subtopics.content:
4. Bar Graph

  • A bar graph shows data using rectangular bars.
  • The length of the bar represents the value.
  • Bars can be drawn vertically or horizontally.

subtopics.title: Double Bar Graph
subtopics.content:
5. Double Bar Graph

Used to compare two sets of data together.

Example: Marks of boys and girls in a class.

subtopics.title: Arithmetic Mean (Average)
subtopics.content:
6. Arithmetic Mean (Average)

The mean is the sum of observations divided by the number of observations.

Mean = Sum of values / Number of values

Example: Numbers = 4, 6, 10
Mean = (4+6+10)/3 = 20/3 ‚âà 6.67

subtopics.title: Median
subtopics.content:
7. Median

Median is the middle value when data is arranged in order.

If there are two middle values, take their average.

Example:
Data = 2, 5, 7 ‚Üí Median = 5
Data = 4, 6, 8, 10 ‚Üí Median = (6+8)/2 = 7

subtopics.title: Mode
subtopics.content:
8. Mode

Mode is the value that occurs most frequently.

Example: Data = 3, 4, 4, 5, 6 ‚Üí Mode = 4

subtopics.title: Probability (Introduction)
subtopics.content:
9. Probability (Introduction)

Probability tells us the likelihood of an event.

P(E) = Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of outcomes

Example: Tossing a coin ‚Üí Probability of getting Heads = 1/2.

questions.question: In the data: 2, 4, 6, 4, 3, 4, 5 ‚Üí The mode is:
questions.explanation: The mode is the value that occurs most frequently in a data set. In the data 2, 4, 6, 4, 3, 4, 5, the number 4 appears three times, which is more frequent than any other number. Therefore, the mode is 4.

questions.question: The mean of numbers 5, 10, 15 is:
questions.explanation: The mean (average) is calculated by adding all the numbers and dividing by the count of numbers. Mean = (5 + 10 + 15) / 3 = 30 / 3 = 10.

questions.question: Which of these is the middle value of 7, 9, 5, 12, 8 when arranged in order?
questions.explanation: To find the median, first arrange the data in ascending order: 5, 7, 8, 9, 12. The middle value is 8, so the median is 8.

questions.question: In a tally chart, |||| represents:
questions.explanation: In a tally chart, each vertical line represents 1, and every fifth line is drawn diagonally across the previous four lines to represent 5. So |||| represents 5.

questions.question: Which graph is best suited to show comparison of two different groups?
questions.explanation: A double bar graph is specifically designed to compare two sets of data side by side. It uses two bars for each category to make comparisons easy.

questions.question: If üçé = 2 apples, then üçéüçéüçéüçé represents:
questions.explanation: If one üçé symbol represents 2 apples, then four üçé symbols represent 4 √ó 2 = 8 apples.

questions.question: The probability of getting a 3 when a die is rolled is:
questions.explanation: A standard die has 6 faces numbered 1 through 6. There is only one favorable outcome (getting a 3) out of 6 possible outcomes. So the probability is 1/6.

questions.question: In the data 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, the median is:
questions.explanation: To find the median, arrange the data in order (already done) and find the middle value. Since there are 5 values, the middle one is the third value, which is 30.

questions.question: A bar graph has bars of different ______.
questions.explanation: In a bar graph, the length (or height) of each bar represents the value of the data it represents. Bars of different lengths show different values.

questions.question: In the data: 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, the mean is:
questions.explanation: The mean is calculated by adding all values and dividing by the number of values. Mean = (12 + 14 + 16 + 18 + 20) / 5 = 80 / 5 = 16.
